title: Public Services Ombudsmen and Administrative Justice: Models, Roles, Methods and Relationships
abstractText:
Public service ombudsmen have a statutory duty to investigate claims of injustice caused by maladministration in the provision of public services- central and local government and the NHS. This project will establish how this duty is currently interpreted  by the ombudsmen and make recommendations as to how they might optimise their potential within the wider administrative justice context and develop new theoretical models of ombudsmen and their work.

The study will focus on the main roles of redressing complaints and improving administration, the methods which they use and are developing, and their relationships with other stakeholders in the emerging administrative justice system which includes the public, the public services agencies, the courts, internal complaints systems, tribunals, auditors, elected representatives and advisory bodies.

The project team while concentrating on public services ombudsmen throughout the UK will also study their counterparts in Australia, Ireland and New Zealand. These countries have arrangements which are broadly similar but have some differences which should help illuminate key issues. The project team will interview the ombudsmen  and a selection of parliamentarians, auditors and advisory bodies. Interviewees in the UK will also include other complaints handling bodies dealing with the police and prisons, child support and tax.
